title: coronavirus uk daily briefings professor david spiegelhalter
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The government’s daily coronavirus briefings are “not trustworthy communication of statistics”, according to a leading scientist who has been advising ministers during the pandemic.Data given during the briefings is “completely embarrassing” and amounts to “number theatre”, said Professor Sir David Spiegelhalter, who sits on the government’s Scientific Advice Group for Emergencies (Sage).Professor&nbspSpiegelhalter pointed out that that daily testing numbers&nbspalso included&nbsptests which had&nbspbeen posted to people and not yet recorded, and&nbspwere therefore “inaccurate”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“We get told lots of big numbers, and precise numbers of tests being done – 96,878,” he told the BBC's Andrew Marr&nbspShow.“Well that’s not how many were done yesterday. It includes tests that were posted out.&nbspWe’re told 31,587 people have died. No they haven’t. It’s far more than that.”The professor, also chair of the Winton Centre for Risk and Evidence Communication at the University of Cambridge, continued: “I think this is not a trustworthy communication of statistics. It’s such a missed opportunity. There’s a public out there who are broadly very supportive of the measures, they’re hungry for details, for facts, for genuine information.How to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?“And yet they get fed this, what I call number theatre, which seems to be coordinated really much more by No 10’s communications team, rather than genuinely trying to inform people about what’s going on.”He added: “I just wish the data was being brought together and presented by people who really knew its strength and limitations and could treat the audience with some respect.”When asked by Marr later on the programme whether, in response to the criticism, the government would rethink the way they present the numbers, communities secretary Robert Jenrick said: “Well, I’m sure there’s ways we can improve these press conferences.“They continue to get large audiences, but they’re designed to inform the public. If there are better ways of presenting the numbers – and I very strongly respect the professor – if we can do that, we should and will do that.”The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailMinisters have cited the views of Professor&nbspSpiegelhalter a number of times during the pandemic.When questioned about the death toll by Labour leader Keir Starmer during prime minister’s questions on Wednesday last week, Boris Johnson said: “I would echo what we’ve heard from Professor David Spiegelhalter and others: that at this stage, I don’t think that international comparisons and the data is yet there to draw all the conclusions that we want.”The message the government is putting out to the public on the pandemic has also been criticised by another member of Sage, behavioural expert Professor Susan Michie who said dropping the “stay home” slogan risked giving people the green light to socialise, jeopardising the gains made by the coronavirus lockdown in.Prof Michie said Mr Johnson's new messaging was “a long way” from being clear and consistent, adding: “This could potentially undermine the good work over the last few weeks that has seen impressively sustained high levels of adherence by the public in what for many are very challenging situations.”It comes as the prime minister is expected to unveil a new colour-coded alert system as he eases some lockdown restrictions in Sunday night’s daily briefing. It is thought he is going&nbspto drop the government’s “stay at home” messaging in favour of “stay alert” – sparking further accusations of mixed messaging and immediate rejections from Scotland and Wales.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - The vice president appeared to be joking, and did not actually deliver any empty boxes.&nbspPPEBut the clip was picked up by Mr Kimmel&nbspin a segment on his show.Mike Pence pretending to carry empty boxes of&nbspPPE&nbspinto a hospital is the perfect metaphor for who he is, and what he's doing. A big box of nothing, delivering another box of nothing, Mr&nbspKimmel&nbspsaid.Mr Kimmel was accused by a member of Mr Pence's campaign staff of selectively editing the clip used on his show.This is absolute garbage spread by @JimmyKimmel, tweeted Jon Thompson, Mr Pence's campaign communications director. Pence is clearly joking about empty boxes &amp if Kimmel showed the full clip from CSPAN, not the one he selectively edited, you see and hear it.Mr Kimmel later issued something of an&nbspapology&nbspon Twitter.It would appear that @vp was joking about carrying empty boxes for a staged publicity stunt. title: coronavirus germany lockdown infection rate cases economy
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Authorities in certain states reopen gyms, museums and zoos amid mounting pressure to lighten restrictionsGermany is&nbsppressing ahead with its plans to further ease nationwide lockdown restrictions – despite the country’s infection rate remaining above the critical threshold for two consecutive days.According to the Robert Koch Institute (RKI), the reproduction rate – the estimated number of people whom a confirmed patient infects – rose to 1.1 on Saturday and Sunday.If accurate, it would suggest that the number of infections is now growing rather than falling,&nbspraising concerns of a second wave across the country.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesNonetheless, the German government, amid mounting political pressure and nationwide protests, is continuing with its plans to kickstart the economy after weeks of life under&nbsplockdown.In the western state of North Rhine-Westphalia (NRW), gyms and sports venues were allowed to open on Monday morning, while restaurants can operate under certain conditions.How to help the elderly and vulnerable during the coronavirusHow to feel less anxious about the coronavirusHow to be productive when working from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsBrandenburg and Baden-Wurttemberg, among other states, are relaxing restrictions on public gatherings. In Bavaria, zoos, museums and libraries have been given the green light to reopen with strict social distancing in place.This follows the earlier reopening of shops, playgrounds, museums, and churches across the country, along with secondary schools only.However, with responsibility for education devolved to Germany’s 16 federal states, some have been moving quicker than others. In Bavaria, one of the country’s worst-hit regions, school openings had been delayed until Monday.To reduce the risk of transmission, class sizes have been cut in half, one-way systems enforced in corridors, and lunch breaks staggered.Masks and gloves have even been handed out among staff and students at some schools, such as the ISR International School on the Rhine, near Dusseldorf.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailEileen Lyons, the school's director, told The Independent that students have also had the opportunity to “choose between virtual classes or physical classes at ISR since 9 March, depending on the level of risk of the students and families”.“This has allowed us to provide continuous lessons from kindergarten through to grade 12,” she added.The green light has also been given for the return of the Bundesliga, Germany’s top football league, which is due to restart next weekend – despite the recent positive tests recorded among Dynamo Dresden’s squad.Germany's chancellor, Angela Merkel, emphasised that people needed to continue to maintain social distancing despite the changes.It's very important to me to again draw attention to the fact that we're entering a new phase of the pandemic and that it will now be necessary, with all the easing of measures, to be sure that people stick to the basic rules ie keeping their distance, wearing mouth and nose protection and showing consideration for each other, Ms Merkel told reporters.The easing of restrictions has been accompanied by nationwide calls for the accelerated lifting of containment measures.On Saturday, thousands of protesters gathered in a number of major German cities, including Frankfurt, Munich, Stuttgart and Berlin, where about 30 people were arrested outside the Reichstag for not obeying social distancing measures.Despite the growing pressure to reopen&nbspsociety, with many of the federal states eager to return to some degree of normality, questions continue to persist over the country’s current course of action, which appears to have sparked a recent&nbspspike in cases.More than 1,250 new confirmed cases were reported on Saturday, many of which were linked to outbreaks in slaughterhouses and nursing homes. Before the lockdown was eased, the number of daily cases had fallen below the 1,000 mark.Many of the 205 people infected in a meat plant in Coesfeld, a city in NRW, were migrant workers from eastern Europe living in shared accommodation. NRW's health minister, Karl-Josef Laumann, said that an estimated 17,000-20,000 employees in all of the state’s 35 slaughterhouses would be tested for the coronavirus, including&nbspall 1,200 workers at the Coesfeld plant.While many have called for greater action in relaxing restrictions, others have criticised the government for moving too quickly.Karl Lauterbach, a Social Democrat lawmaker and professor of epidemiology, has warned that Covid-19 could start spreading again quickly after seeing large crowds out and about on Saturday in his home city of Cologne.“It has to be expected that the R rate will go over 1 and we will return to exponential growth,” Prof Lauterbach said in a tweet. “The loosening measures were far too poorly prepared.”To help contain any future coronavirus clusters, Ms Merkel last week unveiled an “emergency brake” which will require local authorities to reimpose restrictions if the numbers of cases rise above a threshold of 50 per 100,000 people.In recent days, five areas have broken the threshold, including the southern town of Rosenheim, where a number of cases were found in a refugee shelter. It was not immediately clear whether officials would reimpose restrictions across the town or limit measures to the affected asylum centre.Although much has been made of Germany’s rising R rate, the RKI has also warned against jumping to conclusions.The institute said that because of the fluctuations in statistics it could not yet be assessed “whether the trend of new infections, which has been falling in recent weeks, has continued or whether the number of cases has increased again”.The RKI also warned last month&nbspthat the dynamics of the&nbsppandemic should not be judged on the R rate alone. It is an “important factor” but “only one measure among many”, said RKI's president, Lothar Wieler.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: dan wootton ww2 gave us young leaders
story: MY grandfather William Thomas Wootton celebrated his st birthday behind enemy lines in a Belgian village the British Army was trying to liberate from the Germans.As a member of the Royal Engineers, he had landed in Normandy on June ,  — less than a week after D-Day.The next  months of this young lad’s le were filled with unimaginable horrors.Killing enemy soldiers as a Bren gunner on the back of a jeep became routine as our forces pushed through fierce resistance to arrive in Germany in time for VE Day.His story was typical of virtually any member of our greatest generation in combat during World War Two.The boy from Tadworth, Surrey, started the conflict truly terried and was mortied about seeing dead bodies.But within days, indescribable atrocities became the norm.In his later years, he didn’t like to talk about the war, which he said brought out the dark side of men, but opened up to my dad a couple of years before his death from cancer in .One memory that stuck with Grandpa Bill was the day his unit had been in combat and needed to get away quickly.They all piled into a truck under fire and sped off. But a fellow young soldier was running to catch up, so they pulled him in and he sat opposite my grandpa, who askedhe was OK.He replied “yes”, only for his stomach and guts to fall out all over the floor. He was dead within minutes.Because my grandpa was a professional soldier, he wasn’t demobilised and sent home after the war, but was billeted with the family of a German soldier of equal rank as he became part of the occupation forces in the British-run sector of what would become West Germany.Just imagine how hard that must have been: Living with someone who a few weeks earlier you were trying to kill.But my grandpa said: “They were just like us, fighting for their country.”Without wanting to disparage the generations that have followed — mine included — it’s hard to imagine a member of Generation X or a millennial turning such trauma into a positive way of living.But,  years on, there’s very good reason why our leaders today have regularly invoked the unsurpassed generation who came of age during World War Two throughout the current coronavirus crisis.It’s no coincidence this group of fine folk includes the Queen, Sir David Attenborough and Captain Tom Moore, who have all provided the nation with so much inspiration at a time when celebrities, experts and politicians have often looked so deeply inadequate.That gives me some hope that out of our current trauma will come a new great generation of young leaders to shepherd us through the next  years.Maybe I’m naive, but I think the current pain and uncertainty surrounding lockdown could strengthen the character of young people, who have been mollycoddled by teachers and parents for so long.This is the only time since the last world war where the entire globe is engaged in a conflict that has upended le as we know it.We are again surrounded by tragedy, uncertainty and genuine fear.Adults can no longer provide easy assurances or answers to children about when they will be able toto normal le, be it visiting grandparents, going on holiday, shopping for clothes or attending school.While this is a situation no one would ever have wished for, I have a growing optimism that we are never going to take any of those seemingly everyday pursuits for granted again.What’s so striking about the generation who lived through World War Two is their total rejection of unnecessary consumerism. The Queen is a great example of this.She has all the money and privilege in the world, but feels no need to replace her rotary-dial telephone from  at Windsor Castle or wallpaper that dates back to Queen Victoria at Balmoral.I guess anyone who worried about surviving the London Blitz or lived in terror over whether relatives and friends wouldfrom the front line understands that hyper- consumerism is largely unimportant.Grandpa Bill’s future we, Catherine Taylor, my beloved grandma, was  years old and living in South Shields, Tyne and Wear, when World War Two broke out.My great-grandfather, a World War One veteran and coal miner, had resolved to send her to Canada on the SS Athenia.Thank God he changed his mind at the last minute it was the first British ship lost after war was declared.She was instead evacuated to Cockermouth in the Lake District to live with another family, but ed home just as German bombers started targeting the Tyneside shipyards and suburbs of Newcastle.My proud Geordie grandma Rua, as I called her, spent night after night in a not-at-all-sturdy brick shelter in their back garden, listening to the bombs drop nearby, on one occasion on her actual street.It was no le for a teenager. She carried her gas mask everywhere, knitted for airmen, joined bucket lines to put out fires and grieved for the  people of Newcastle lost in the bombings.Then there was the daily fear of the “telegram boy” arriving with messages of relatives killed in combat.But determined to help the war effort further, she dropped out of school and in  joined the Auxiliary Territorial Service — the women’s branch of the British Army during the war.This week I listened back to an oral history I recorded with my late grandma in the Nineties where she recounted her experiences of the time in her typically stoic and understated manner.I noticed that any time I tried to guide her towards talking about the emotional cost of her teenage years being overtaken by tragedy, she batted it away.“We didn’t talk much about nasty things,” she said softly. “I hated the bombing and I was terried. Looking back, I think we got through it with lots of prayers.“The war taught you about tragedy in people’s lives but you just battled on regardless.”In fact, grandma said the positives included being “united as a nation” and “people caring for one another”.Was she ever depressed “Le was entirely dferent then. We did sort of lose our teenage years in a way because they weren’t happy go lucky.“Teenagers in England now have the chance to go on the Continent and travel around at a very small cost.We couldn’t do anything like that. You just carried on. You had to.”There is very little comparison to what we are going through at the moment with the six years of death and destruction in World War Two.But it’s impossible to deny that the travel, socialising and happy-go- lucky approach to le we had become accustomed to has been stolen from us, for now at least.Youngsters previously so obsessed with how many people watched their latest dance video on TikTok are starting to think twice about what really matters.They’re volunteering. They’re cooking for family members. They’re talking on Zoom to isolated elderly relatives.Millennials who had become turned off and disillusioned with public le during the partisan Brexit wars are starting to re-engage with politics, aware of the real-le impact of decisions made by our leaders.Ridiculous snowflake battles around identity politics and social issues now feel meaningless.I hope and pray that when we look back in many decades’ time, we will be talking about how the historic coronavirus pandemic of  helped create a new greatest generation in the same way the end of World War Two did  years earlier.But tomorrow my thoughts will be entirely with all four of my grandparents — Bill, Cath, RAF airman John George Wheeler and London Blitz survivor Sylvia Jean Cook — who put their coming of age aside for the good of the country.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: we must find out why coronavirus doles out its grisly rations so unevenly
story: But the faces of those who have died saving lives of ­others in this pandemic — doctors, nurses, hospital porters — tell a dferent story.What is especially dangerous about this virus is we don’t know why it doles out its grisly rations so unevenly.It would be easy to imagine this is the product of some kind of biological dference.But so far evidence shows it hits Caribbean people at least twice as hard as our African cousins – and we share many of the same genes.Some have jumped to ­the conclusion that people of colour are likely to be poorer and live in crowded districts.But the virus has affected well-paid surgeons from spacious suburbs as well as low-paid cleaners in tower blocks.Analysis of over , deaths showed Black Caribbean Britons are three times as likely to die as those Brits of Bangladeshi heritage. ­Scientists studying the problem aren’t helped by overly sensitive authorities making it impossible to keep detailed info on ethnic communities, for fear of being called racist.But this isn’t just an issue for people of colour.Leaving any vulnerable group untreated isn’t just a threat to them – it risks creating a pool from which the virus can rise again to strike everyone.I pray that we find an answer soon.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mistakes government brits proud
story: “HOW on earth did it come to this ” Labour’s Sir Keir Starmer quietly asked Boris Johnson when they faced each other for the first time at Prime Minister’s Questions.And it is the question that will torment our country for many years to come.Unlike Jeremy Corbyn, Labour’s new leader asked his question with courtesy, restraint and calm. There was no implication that the wicked Tories were plotting to murder us all in our beds. There was no attempt to score cheap party-political points against a PM who is freshly back from death’s door.Yet Starmer’s concern was real. And it is a concern we all share.Why DO we have the worst death toll in Europe There will be time enough for a full-scale inquiry after we have won this war. But we would not be humanwe did not ask the question now ­— is the UK really the sick man of Europe  Are we truly doing so much worse than every other country Much is made of our death toll exceeding that of Italy.It sometimes feels aswe are locked in some grotesque Champions League of human misery.Yet the statistics can be misleading. Spain, for example, does not count deaths in care homes — we do. Germany only counts care home fatalities when Covid- has been diagnosed before death. And China — officially with fewer than , deaths — lies through its teeth, and has lied from the very start.There are factors that no British Government could do anything about. According to Wednesday’s data from the Office for National Statistics, ,, of us are jammed into this overpopulated little island ­— six million more than Italy.The UK is a crowded country and our capital is a global city — the perfect petri dish for a global pandemic.Thirteen million Brits are clinically obese and this virus is particularly murderous among the overweight. There are .million Brits over the age of  and the virus is pitiless among the elderly.Yet it is painfully obvious that massive cock-ups have been made.Because our politicians are always terried of looking racist, British airports were left open for far too long. Around million people were let into the UK between January  and March , even as the virus rampaged across the world.Yet just  travellers arriving from Wuhan were made to self-isolate.We have relied on the likes of China and Turkey to make kit for our health carers, when so much of what they produce is shoddy trash that can’t even be used, including the , gowns from Turkey currently impounded at a Heathrow warehouse after inspectors found the gear was “useless”.London’s Labour Mayor Sadiq Khan cut Tube trains, ensuring NHS staff travelled to work on dangerously packed carriages.So don’t just blame the Tories.Testing has been — still is — pathetically slow, choked by paperwork.But perhaps the biggest mistake of all is that this Government has been far too eager to defer to the “experts” — even when those very same “experts” have got it spectacularly wrong in the past.Professor Neil Ferguson, the key scientic adviser who was the brains behind this national lockdown, was caught this week taking his daily exercise by mounting his married mistress, thereby breaking the strict rules he designed for the rest of us. The bonking boffin’s rank hypocrisy is bad enough.But what should worry us more is Ferguson’s defective crystal ball. Was it made in China  Neil Ferguson’s team produced the we-are-all-doomed research that predicted more than , would die without nationwide house arrest.Yet Professor McPantsdown’s previous predictions are so inaccurate they make Paul The Octopus look like Nostradamus.The preachy prof told us in  that , of us could die from mad cow disease. There were just  deaths.In  Mystic Neil warned that million could die worldwide from bird flu. The final number was .More recently, the randy epidemiologist predicted that Sweden’s relaxed attitude to the virus would lead to , dead Swedes by May . The number was ,.If the sex-mad scientist has been so wrong in the past, then why did the Government gullibly assume that Ferguson was so right about Covid- Common sense should have told us Ferguson is just a fallible scientist who has previously peddled flawed extrapolations — not some bespectacled Yoda. And from the reluctance to close our airports to mistaking Ferguson for God, we have sometimes been short of good old British common sense in recent weeks.Tonight Boris addresses the nation on plans to start very gently easing the lockdown. Many people are understandably worried about going out into the world again.So many have died. So many families have been shattered. So many of the bravest and the best have paid the ultimate price for caring for strangers.But are we really the sick man of Europe Despite our horric death count, this country can feel proud of the way it has conducted itself during this national emergency. Mistakes have certainly been made — just as they were made in the war that we have remembered over the past few days.But the British people have reacted to this historic challenge with patience, resilience and quiet courage. There is a feeling of national unity now that I have never known in my letime.From the courage of NHS workers to the kindness of neighbours, we have witnessed the best of our people during this crisis.The sick man of Europe  Not us. Over the past six weeks, I have never felt prouder to be British.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Fashion model Harriet Rose ditched the catwalk to work in a care home in Herne Bay, Kent, where she has been in lockdown for the past month.“To say it’s been tough would be an understatement,” says Harriet, who had been modelling in Paris for three years.“We have been so lucky to have not lost any resident or member of staff. The quite literal blood, sweat and tears, hundreds of hours on minimal sleep and not giving up were all worth it!”To elect to work in a care home when you could be a model in Paris takes some guts.The Queen said: “Those who come after us will say the Britons of this generation were as strong as any.”Looking at Harriet Rose, you can only conclude the Queen is right.Two singers introduced the world to the glory of Jamaican music.More than ten years before Bob Marley made reggae a critical and commercial success, My Boy Lollipop by Millie – three minutes of euphoric ska – in  became the first million-selling single to come out of Jamaica.Now Millie Small has died in London at the age of  and the reason she feels like so much more than a one-hit wonder is because she gave millions of us our first taste of Jamaica.Marley did it biggest. But Millie did it first.THE “definitive story” of Harry and Meghan’s struggles is to be called, Finding Freedom.That’s a great title for a book.As long as you are Nelson Mandela, Mahatma Gandhi or Martin Luther King.Not spoilt Tinseltown royalty.Adele,  last Tuesday, is almost unrecognisable after dropping seven stone. And did you ever see her looking healthier and happier As obesity sweeps the Western world, Adele should be an inspiration to millions.“In times like these,” said Sophie Ellis-Bextor in her most recent Instagram “After Party”, “who doesn’t need a little Julie Andrews ”Sophie then launched into a rousing version of My Favourite Things.Great performance! Although the best bit was Sophie’s young son Ray refusing to play along, watching Mum strutting her funky stuff with arms folded and a sulky expression.“Is it cheering you up, Ray ”“No.”Sophie looks like she would love to get back up on stage.Young Ray looks as though he would love to see her go.ACTRESS Florence Pugh has revealed that her dog Billie dug up a large sex toy that was buried in her garden.“Billie was so proud,” says Florence.Stan, our innocent Cavalier King Charles Spaniel, contents himself with a classic Kong chew toy.You don’t know what you’re missing, Stan.Not again! Serial lockdown-flouting lout Kyle Walker scored a ­hat-trick of Covid- breaches in just  hours.Does the Manchester City moron understand how offensive this is He should talk to Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola, whose beloved mother died from Covid- only last month.Apparently, Walker would love to join the nation clapping NHS carers next Thursday night. But he has a previous engagement.TECH bro Elon Musk and his partner Claire Boucher have called their new baby boy X Æ A-.That’s the st-century equivalent of all those rock stars who called their kids wacky names like Zowieand Dweezil .As I recall, Zowie had started calling himself Joe before he finished school and is now Duncan Jones.Little X Æ A- Musk will be calling himself Colin before too long. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris convice brits overcome coronavirus
story: BORIS JOHNSON needs to do some straight talking tonight.The PM has overcome Covid-. He now needs to convince frightened Britons that we can safely overcome the pandemic’s brutal economic impact.Boris himself admits that we are entering a new danger zone. But there is little time left to get Britain back on track before the economy slides into meltdown.He needs to spell out when and how we can resume our everyday lives — without it damaging our health. The scale of the PM’s challenge is revealed in our poll today.Seven weeks after people were asked to accept unprecedented restrictions on their lives, a staggering  per cent are opposed to any easing at this time. The public’s response to this challenge has been magnicent, but there is an urgent need to get Britain working again.The cost of the furlough scheme alone is already an eye-watering £billion and is spiralling by an unsustainable £.billion a day.Our poll shows most people are far more afraid of a second wave of coronavirus than the risk of losing their jobs. Only one in  believe the measures should end, and just four per cent favour an immediateto work.Boris must use his address to the nation tonight to instil confidence that “unlockdown” will be measured and safe.But he must not underplay the uncomfortable truth: It is time people grit their teeth and get the economy going again.Give it to us straight, PM.CHANCELLOR Rishi Sunak’s furlough scheme has thrown millions of British workers a generous leline during the crisis.But it is outrageous when the mega-rich take advantage of it at the expense of the taxpayer.The latest are the Hinduja brothers, worth £billion, who are using the Government’s hand-outs to pay employees at one of their firms.As Britain’s richest family, why can’t they pay staff out of their own deep pockets CHINA has an enormous stake in Britain, with investments worth over £billion.As one of the world’s most powerful economies, it will also be crucial to post-Brexit trade.But this secretive and authoritarian country must not be let off the hook over its role in the coronavirus outbreak.Britain has been too slow to join other nations in pressing for a full inquiry. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trevor kavanagh lockdown terrible mistake
story: “I had dficulty not wanting Boris Johnson to die. I wanted him to die,” she told Channel  cheerleaders.The Harry Potter star is the authentic voice of Corbynistas who loathe this Prime Minister with a visceral hatred.If they can’t dance on his grave, the Dementors will do everything possible to kill his political career.Covid- has morphed from a battle for the nation’s health into a lethal struggle to stop Boris leading Britain successfully out of lockdown.An early victory came last night, as the PM unveiled his new slow-motion escape motto.Some ministers hoped for: “Back to work. Go to school. Save the economy.”Instead we heard a feeble “Stay alert. Control the virus. Save lives.”This is a Prime Minister paralysed by indecision, kicking himself for unforced errors, terried of being blamed for every new death.Downing Street is now hostage to the health-and-safety mafia, whipped into line by opportunist public sector unions who have, to coin a phrase, taken back control.Teaching unions, already on guaranteed public sector pay, even want to restrict some online lessons for education-hungry kids.Transport unions are making Tube, rail and bus travel impossible with draconian social distancing.Health unions blame ministers for blunders made by NHS and Public Health England managers.We are in thrall to a shroud-waving public sector “blob” warning of mass fatalitiesthe Government makes one  step.We must heed the experts who swallowed “Bonking Professor” Neil Ferguson’s crackpot forecasts of half a million dead without lockdown.They are the same experts whose advice on testing, PPE and care homes led to one of the world’s biggest death tolls.The nation’s long-term physical, mental and economic health is being held to ransom by a bug which has virtually no impact on children, young adults and most people under .That same low-risk generation faces a potentially catastrophic price for a disease which should leave them and their parents free toalmost immediately to normal le.Coronavirus is an old person’s disease. Out of ten million under-s in Britain, just two have sadly died from Covid-.For under-s, the risk is a “trivial” one or two per million, says respected statistician Sir David Spiegelhalter. Little more than the chance of dying by accident.For over-s, he says the risk is “ten thousand times” as high.This is no consolation for elderly victims, but it does suggest a speedy route back to a new normal with productive under-s kick-starting the economy.Getting people back to work will be hard. The work ethic propelling us out of bed each morning has been sapped by warm spring sunshine, online food and wine and a Treasury- funded cost of living subsidy.People are enjoying paid-for-time with their families. they are also scared witless by sermons about death and disaster and Downing Street’s daily mortality rate briefings.One day there will be a public inquiry. Everyone is covering their tracks.With hindsight, global lockdown is likely to be judged a terrible mistake, forced on a panic-stricken world by China’s authoritarian example.Sweden alone rejected lockdown, keeping schools open, and the economy ticking over, yet its death toll is lower per head than Britain, France, Spain and Italy.Former Swedish medical chief, Professor Johan Giesecke, believes we overreacted to a disease which is just twice as severe as winter flu and cannot be avoided anyway.“I don’t think you can stop it,” he says, “it’s like a tsunami sweeping across Europe.“We should do what we can to slow it so the health service can cope, but let it pass.”But he won’t say this in public.He will have seen the bizarre charges of betrayal and “fat shaming” against singer Adele for daring to lose seven stone.Yet Liverpool University researchers say obesity increases the risk of death from coronavirus by  per cent.Boris should say loud and clear that fat can be fatal. Losing weight prolongs le.Our health service, by the way, has coped brilliantly.Prof Giesecke says there are three golden rules: “Wash your hands, keep social distance, trust the people.”After Brexit, Boris should know more than most he can trust the people.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rav wilding returning frontline cop
story: The -year-old is going back to his old role as a detective constable and says the move has the backing of pregnant we Jill. title: unions keep members away from work
story: The bosses of the UKs biggest four unions united to insist they would try to block No’s plans to ease Britain back to work unless it ploughs millions more into health and safety monitoring.The leaders of Unite, Unison, the General, Municipal, Boilermakersand the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workersmade their warning in a letter in The Observer yesterday.The five union barons warned they will not recommend their millions of membersto work unless the Government guarantees the right policies and practices are in place to make workplaces safe.But Tory MPs blasted them for failing to support the Government’s efforts to restart the economy after weeks of lockdown.David Jones fumed: “The unions should be supporting the Government and the people of this country in the task of rebuilding our economy as soon as it is safe to do so.“Nobody wants inadequate standards, but it looks very much as though the unions are cynically trying to impose additional burdens on business just at the time when we need to get going again.”In their letter, the union chiefs added: “After years of cuts, the government must boost funding for pro-active monitoring and health and safety enforcement. And we need a public information campaign so rogue bosses face sanctions.“The trade union movement wants to be able to recommend the governments back-to-work plans. But for us to do that we need to ensure that ministers have listened and that we stay safe and save lives at work too.Tories accused the unions of playing politics with the coronavirus crisis.Henry Smith, Conservative MP for Crawley in West Sussex, said: “So long as safety measures are in place there can be no excuse for unions seeking to prevent ato work when appropriate.“Unions have a duty to support the recovery of our nation’s economy out of the Covid- crisis, not play left wing politics.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rhetoric wont save economy
story: WE urge all Brits to keep in mind two truths over the coming weeks.One: Coronavirus is a deadly and highly contagious disease, and although we are over the first peak of infection, it still poses a huge threat to this nation.Two: The Government can’t bail out Britain indefinitely. Andwe are to avoid bankruptcies, whopping tax rises and mass unemployment, the country mustto work ASAP.The conditional plan Boris Johnson laid out last night for eventually reopening society delicately balances these two facts. And The Sun cautiously welcomes it.Now, the Prime Minister must get the leaders of Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales  per cent on side.We know that’s easier said than done: Nicola Sturgeon thrives on creating trouble.But she must be told that the public won’t forgive politiciansthey fail to work together while the nation is under siege.And we stand the best chance of defeating this devilish enemywe act as a United Kingdom.The PM must also urgently clear up some questions around the new rules.Does “limit contact with other people” mean we can have contact with others as long as we keep it limited  If so, what’s the limit  And which other people What exactly does “drive to other destinations mean ” Are we now allowed on cross-country jaunts to the coast  Or just five miles down the road And how on earth are parents working in industries such as manufacturing and construction supposed to go back to work while their kids are stuck at home We accept that we’re being asked to use some level of common sense. But clarity is a crucial weapon in this particular war. And woolly guidance which is wide open to abuse really could cost lives.Last night, the Prime Minister proved once again that he’s an excellent speaker.But our economy is slowly suffocating. And rhetoric won’t save it.THE prospect of the Queen withdrawing from public le for the foreseeable future will come as a real blow to Brits.Our fabulous monarch has a knack for perfectly capturing the mood of the nation — and she is the constant we all need in this unpredictable new world.That said, it comes as a relief to us that she and her advisers are taking social distancing seriously.Her Majesty is  years old, and the most important thing is that she stays safe and well.One day, she’ll meet us again.And in the meantime, her wise and wonderful TV addresses will serve as a great comfort to us all. title: coronavirus uk live update lockdown
story: BORIS Johnson has said he hopes for a vaccine after top government chiefs warned we may never discover one.The Chief Scientic Adviser Patrick Vallance today pointed out the SARS virusis still wihtout one.It comes amid the new lockdown plan which could see hotels reopened by July, as well as a number of Britsto work and childrento school in a few months.The PM was grilled last night along with Professor Chris Whitty and Scientic Adviser Mr Vallance.When asked about the possibility of a vaccine, the trio remained positive but sombre - with the PM saying he hoped for one soon and insisting good things were happening at ious research centres across the UK.This comes as deaths in the UK increased to , after  more deaths were recorded today - the lowest daily rise in six weeks.Follow our coronavirus live blog for all the latest news and updates...Care homes in the UK faced funding cuts unless they took in coronavirus patients, it has been revealed. Sky News reports several councils threatened to reduce cash flow intended to help the homes deal with the outbreak unless they took in Covid- patients.One anonymous source from an unnamed care home said: #My anguish and sadness is purely arisen from the thoughtless and neglectful conduct of the local authorities demanding that providers admit into their homes COVID- positive and untested residents.#This has undoubtedly caused a huge spike in infections and resulted in deaths that were avoidable.#A Tory MP has been criticised for saying the Welsh parliament should be abolished for undermining the Prime Minister.Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford told his country today: “Welsh law applies in Wales” as the PM unveiled his lockdown-exit ‘roadmap’.But Daniel Kawczynski said the parliament was#unnecessary#and was #picking apart our UK#.He added: “Their undermining of PM at a time of crisis will I hope start a debate in Wales longer term as to whether or not to continue with this expensive and unnecessary body.”Vice-chair of the Conservative party’s Welsh arm, Darren Miller said his comments #are not consistent with our party policy at either a Welsh or UK level#.And former Plaid Cymru leader Leanne Wood said the Shrewsbury MPs outburst was because #because the Welsh government has stopped him going to his nearest beach#.Brits will be able to holiday in France as the PM and Emmanuel Macron draw up plans.The pair are brainstorming a three country ‘safe corridor’ travel plan in a bid to save summer holidays.Under the two leaders’ blueprint, all travellers will be able to cross freely between Britain and France despite tough new coronavirus restrictionsBoris Johnson has said he knows those still shielding during coronavirus will feel “anguish” as the lockdown is gradually eased. Speaking in the House of Commons earlier today he said: #I know that easing restrictions for the many will only increase the anguish of those who must remain shielded. “So the Government will look at every possible way of supporting the most vulnerable.#In an interview with Channel , the Surrey handyman said: “Its sort of leaving it up to us a little bit … to you know,you feel safe to do so then do it.”In an interview with Channel , the Surrey handyman said: “Its sortof leaving it up to us a little bit … to you know,you feel safe to do so then do it.”“Its not really hard to understand,” he added.It comes as scores of Brits have come forward to defend the PMs plans amid criticisms of being unclear.Britons have been urged to stay away from beauty spots as the Government yesterday announced travel would be allowed for exercise.Authorities from travel hotspots across the UK urged people not to flood their beaches, lakes and villages, while Brighton council told would-be tourists to just #stay away#.Cornwall, Cumbria and the Cotswolds were among some of the regions which said they wouldnt be welcoming tourists despite the lockdown easing.Police watched on as crowds of gathered outside a Cork church to mourn the loss of two brothers from the Cash family # despite social distancing rules.The mourners were seen mingling outside Farranree Church on the north side of the city as the funeral mass took place inside.Concerned locals watched on, claiming the group showed little or no regard for social distancing.Many were seen shaking hands, embracing and standing in groups as the funeral cortege made its way to the church, the Cork Beo reported.The publication said people appeared to have travelled great distances to attend the funeral as cars and camper vans seen parked outside the church displayed registrations from dferent counties around Ireland and from the UK.The Government revealed as part of lockdown restrictions you can meet one person outside your household # as long as you’re outdoors and are socially-distanced. But the First Secretary of State today then sparked confusion minutes later when he said that one person could meet two of their parents at ONCE.Mr Raab was asked on Radio  this morning: #From Wednesday, you can meet one person from outside your household. Does that mean you cant meet two relatives at the same time, for example, parents #He replied: #As from Wednesday, people can go outside to parks and certain sports where you can keep social distancing at m, together, with others members from their own home.#If you are going to the park and you can stay m apart, you could meet up with other members of your household.#And he was asked again: #So, you cannot meet two parents at the same time #He added: #You couldthey are two metres apart.#Step one: Using the scissors cut a line across the width of the t-shirt around cmStep two: From the top of the right hand corner of the fabric, measure cm below this and then make a cm horizontal cut through both sides of the fabricStep three: The next step is to cut downwards until you reach cm above the edge. Now make another cm cut that runs parallel to the bottom to make a rectangle that can be thrown away.Step four: Now, to make the ties that secure the mask you need two long strips of fabric. Then unfold the main piece of fabric and place over the mouth and nose to secure. This then needs to be tied around the head and around the neck.The government have revealed coronavirus testing will be rolled out to teachers, staff and pupils who have symptoms as schools prepare tosome kids to the classroom next month.It comes as Ministers try to reassure worried parents its safe for children toto school.Kids won’t be asked to wear masks, either nor will teachers and staff.Prof Chris Whitty tonight reassured Brits the risk of the virus to children is “very, very low”.He said it’s “one of the only good things” about the virus.Class sizes will be cut in half as some children couldto school as of June .Classes will be slashed to no more than , and pupils sat apart to try to limit any spread of coronavirus.Ministers admit they cannot keep classmates two metres away from each other all day.So instead these mini classes will be self-contained ‘bubbles’ and not allowed to mix with other kids at the school, new guidelines published tonight say.Lunch, play breaks and daily drop off times will all be staggered to stop pupils meeting each other outside of their little groups.British schoolchildren could be required to attend dferent schools as the lockdown eases.The Government has said some children couldto school as early as June .New measures will be in place to encompass as much social distancing as possible # butschools dont have enough resources, parents may have to send their kids to a nearby school instead.The UK’s death toll is at least , higher this year than it has been on average for the last five years.Figures recorded across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland include deaths from all causes # but are considerably higher since coronavirus began to ravish Britain.The , excess deaths which occurred this year are unlikely to all be due to coronavirus # although the deadly bug, which has so far killed , people across the UK, counts for a large proportion.The Prime Minister this evening encouraged workers to speak to their employers before ing to work.He reiterated no-one should be forced to work in conditions without appropriate social distancing and encouraged anyone who may have issues with childcare to continue to work from home.For more information on ing to work, read our article here. Asked about who to trust with #conflicting statements# between Scotlands First Minister and himself Boris Johnson reiterated a #four nation approach# would be taken to easing lockdown. He said its #entirely right# devolved nations will take a slightly dferent approach.Prof Chris Whitty said it is important to reinforce that coronavirus is only serious in a #minority of cases#.He said a signicant proportion of the population will never get Covid, while a high number of people will have it asymptomatically.Of those with symptoms, Prof Whitty said # per cent of people will have a mild disease, and be in bed for a couple of days, but not need to see a doctor#.An unfortunate minority will end up in hospital needing oxygen treatment, while a #small minority will then end up in critical care#, he added.#If you look at the curves, because of the work the whole country has done, they are coming down,# Prof Whitty said.He estimated that around one per cent of people die of coronavirus in the UK, adding that number could be lower.#I want to reinforce a sense of perspective. We cant get away from the fact thatwe left the virus to run we would be in a situation with more deaths and the NHS overrun.#The Prime Minister has confirmed anyone travelling between Ireland and the UK wont be subject to the new mandatory -day quarantine.He also said anyone travelling between GreatBritain and Northern Ireland wont need to isolate either.The Chief Medical Officer has said the coronavirus risk to children is #very, very low#.He added it was the #only good thing# about coronavirus.Chief Scientic Officer, Prof Sir Patrick Vallance said we cant guarantee a vaccine to combat coronavirus, pointing out we still dont have one for Sars.Sir Patrick said there are encouraging signs from the trials at Oxford University and other universities. But, he cautioned: #Itsa very tough thing to do# so far, so good. The chances are higher, but you never know until you get one.#Other options include drug treatments, and Sir Patrick said he would be #surprised#we dont end up with something to tackle Covid- # adding hopefully we will have both a vaccine and treatments.Chief Scientic Adviser, Prof Sir Patrick Vallance said it is #very, very important# that we move through the three stages slowly, to avoid pushing the rate of infection # the R value # up above one.He said the new Covid alert system that is being put in place, is crucial to let us know where we are on that scale.Sir Patrick said #we must all be alert during this, in terms of hand washing and understanding the role we play#, adding thatthe public does not play their part, infections could increase and stricter lockdown measures will have to be reintroduced.Asked this evening whether the UK could be living with lockdown measures not just in  but for the foreseeable future, the PM said he couldnt say when measures will end. He saidpossible there will be #more tubes, more busses, more trains# as Brits slowlyto work.The extra transport should help to ease stress on social distancing measures, and help to avoid packed commutes.Englands top doctor, Prof Chris Whitty said that the plan is designed to help the country take #very small steps# to make sure we dont see an increase in transmission again.He said while the risk of transmission outside is #much lower# its not without risk, which is why social distancing rules are still so important.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus adapting humans spread faster
story: CORONAVIRUS may be adapting to humans - making it spread faster, scientists are warning.Researchers from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine have found evidence for mutations in some strains of the deadly bug that suggest the pathogen may be changing after jumping from bats to humans.And the say the mutations may help the virus infect more people and spread rapidly around the world.It comes as more than . million have been infected with coronavirus globally, with the death toll currently standing at over ,.The scientists issued their warning after analysing , coronavirus genomes from  countries - that have been uploaded to two major genetics databases since the pandemic began.They studied the genetic makeup of the virus and examined how it has ersied into dferent strains and looked for signs that it was adapting to its human host.And they found that while the virus is stable, some have gained mutations, including two genetic changes that alter the critical “spike protein” the virus uses to infect human cells.The spike protein are armatures on the outside of the virus that it uses to grab and penetrate the outer walls of human and animal cells.In particular, the scientists warned that while it is unclear how the mutations affects the virus, since the changes arose independently in dferent countries they may help the virus sp easily.Martin Hibberd, professor of emerging infectious diseases and a senior author on the unpublished study, that has yet to be peer reviewed, said the evidence for mutations points out the need for global surveillance of the virus so that more worrying changes are picked up quickly.He told : This is exactly what we need to look out for.People are making vaccines and other therapies against this spike protein because it seems a very good target. We need to keep an eye on it and make sure that any mutations don’t invalidate any of these approaches.Early on in the coronavirus outbreak, scientists revealed that the new coronavirus is “ to , times” more efficient at infecting people than Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome– which killed  people in a year in  .This is because the shape of its spike protein allows it to bind to human cells more efficiently than Sars.The dference may have helped the latest coronavirus infect more people and spread rapidly around the world.Mutations in the spike protein are concerning - particularly as it is the main target of leading vaccines around the world, andit changes too much those vaccines may no longer work.Other potential therapies, such as synthetic antibodies that home in on the spike protein, could be less effective, too.Prof Hibberd added: This is an early warning - eventhese mutations are not important for vaccines, other mutations might be and we need to maintain our surveillance so we are not caught out by deploying a vaccine that only works against some strains.”In their study, the researchers identied two broad groups of coronavirus that have now spread globally.Of the two spike mutations, one was found in  viruses around the world, with the other present in only .The study shows that, until January, one group of coronaviruses in China escaped detection because they had a mutation in the genetic region that early tests relied on.More recent tests detect all of the known types of the virus.A team of scientists last month proved coronavirus wasn’t made in a lab by analysing the genetic template for spike proteins - silencing conspiracy theories.They found that the spike proteins had evolved to effectively target a feature on the outside of human cells which blood pressure.And the spike proteins were so effective at binding the human cells, in fact, that the scientists concluded it was the result of natural selection and not the product of genetic engineering.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new plan stay safe coronavirus lockdown eases
story: BRITS have today been given official guidance on how to stay safe and avoid catching coronavirus while out in public.Boris Johnson published a y plan to get the country back to school and work - without risking a huge second wave of infections.And the -page document includes new Covid- guidance including wearing face masks on public transport and in some shops where social distancing is not possible.Similarly, the Government have advised people to continue washing their hands, work from homepossible and travel by walking or cycling.Brits are also recommended to wash their clothes regularly and keep their home well ventilated, in the document.In a stark warning to the public, the guidance says: It is your responsibility to adopt these principles wherever possible.All of us, as customers, visitors, employees or employers, need to make changes to lower the risk of transmission of the virus.Here, we take you through exactly what the new advice is.The Government says to keep your distance from people outside your household, recognising this will not always be possible.The risk of infection increases the closer you are to another person with the virus and the amount of time you spend in close contact: you are very unlikely to be infectedyou walk past another person in the street.Public Health England recommends trying to keep m away from people as a precaution. However, this is not a rule and the science is complex.The key thing is to not be too close to people for more than a short amount of time, as much as you can.Keep your hands and face as clean as possible. Wash your hands often using soap and water, and dry them thoroughly.Use sanitiser where available outside your home, especially as you enter a building and after you have had contact with surfaces. Avoid touching your face.. Wet your hands with water. Apply enough soap to cover your hands. Rub your hands together. Use one hand to rub the back of the other hand and clean in between the fingers. Repeat with other hand. Rub your hands together and clean in between your fingers. Rub the back of your fingers against your palms. Rub your thumb using your other hand. Do the same with the other thumb. Rub the tips of your fingers on the palm of your other hand. Repeat with the other hand. Rinse your hands with water. Dry your hands completely with a disposable towel. Use the disposable towel to turn off the tapWork from homeyou can. Many people can do most or all of their work from home, with the proper equipment and adjustments.Your employer should support you to find reasonable adjustments to do this. However, not all jobs can be done from home.If your workplace is open and you cannot work from home, you can travel to work.Avoid being face to face with peoplethey are outside your household.You are at higher risk of being directly exposed to respiratory droplets released by someone talking or coughing when you are within m of someone and have face-to-face contact with them.You can lower the risk of infectionyou stay side-to-side rather than facing people.Reduce the number of people you spend time with in a work setting where you can.You can lower the risks of transmission in the workplace by reducing the number of people you come into contact with regularly, which your employer can support where practical by changing sht patterns and rotas to match you with the same team each time and splitting people into smaller, contained teams.You can lower the risks of transmission by reducing the number of people you come into close contact with, so avoid peak travel times on public transport where possible, for example.Businesses should take reasonable steps to avoid people being gathered together, for example by allowing the use of more entrances and exits and staggering entry and exit where possible.If you have to travelthink about how and when you travel.To reduce demand on the public transport network, you should walk or cycle wherever possible. If you have to use public transport, you should try and avoid peak times.Employers should consider staggering working hours and expanding bicycle storage facilities, changing facilities and car parking to help.Wash your clothes regularly. There is some evidence that the virus can stay on fabrics for a few days, although usually it is shorter, soyou are working with people outside your household wash your clothes regularly.Changing clothes in workplaces should only normally be considered where there is a high risk of infection or there are highly vulnerable people, such as in a care home.If you need to change your clothes avoid crowding into a changing room.Here, Laundryheap CEO Deyan Dimitrov shares his top tips on how to wash your clothes to ensure you banish Covid-.. The hotter the betterOur core body temperature runs at an average of C, and provides the ideal conditions for bacteria and viruses to thrive.This meansyou’re looking to fight off the dreaded coronavirus, the much revered C wash might not always pack the punch needed.Most viruses won’t survive in temperatures over C, so you could opt for this setting items that are particularly germ ridden and washed less often, like tea towels, bedding, bath towels, gloves, scarves, and children’s clothing.. Take extra stepsExtreme heat and freezing temperatures can stop bacteria from multiplying, soyou’re doing laundry, take the extra steps and throw your washed items into the tumble drier for  minutes for some added heat and germ killing action.Equally,you’re looking for the motivation to iron, this is it! Iron temperatures can reach over C - not much can survive that.. Clean machinesWashing machines are criminally neglected from our cleaning agendas.But once you realise just how much dirt and grime these machines can harbour, you won’t be taking the risk again.Avoid contaminating your clothes with the machine itself by pouring a cup of white vinegar directly into the drum and starting a hot wash cycle of at least C.Try this every month to avoid any build up of soap, mould and bacteria.. Get the formula rightToo much detergent will create extra soap suds which will cling to your laundry and trap dirt there, rather than lt it away.Similarly, an excess of suds will only create further build-up of soap scum in your machine.Instead, opt for the recommended dosage, and when it comes to fabric softener, try giving white vinegar a go instead of chemical alternatives.. Disinfect effectivelyWhen someone in the home has been poorly, be sure to disinfect quickly and effectively.Handle all bedding and clothing with rubber gloves and wash straight away - never leave to sit in a hamper!Keep indoor places well ventilated. Evidence suggests that the virus is less likely to be passed on in well-ventilated buildings and outdoors.In good weather, try to leave windows and doors open in places where people from dferent households come into contact – or move activity outdoorsyou can.Use external extractor fans to keep spaces well ventilated and make sure that ventilation systems are set to maximise the fresh air flow rate.Heating and cooling systems can be used at their normal temperature settings.If you can, wear a face covering in an enclosed space where social distancing isn’t possible and where you will come into contact with people you do not normally meet.This is most relevant for short periods indoors in crowded areas, for example on public transport or in some shops.The evidence suggests that wearing a face covering does not protect you, but it may protect othersyou are infected but have not developed symptoms.If you have symptoms of Covid-you and your household should isolate at home: wearing a face covering does not change this.A face covering is not the same as the surgical masks or respirators used as part of personal protective equipment by healthcare and other workers these supplies should continue to be reserved for those who need them to protect against risks in their workplace, such as health and care workers and those in industrial settings like those exposed to dust hazards.Face coverings should not be used by children under the age of two or those who may find it dficult to manage them correctly, for example primary school age children unassisted, or those with respiratory conditions.It is important to use face coverings properly and wash your hands before putting them on and taking them off.You should follow the advice given to you by your employer when at work.Employers have a duty to assess and manage risks to your safety in the workplace. The Government has issued guidance to help them do this.This includes how to make adjustments to your workplace to help you maintain social distance.It also includes guidance on hygiene as evidence suggests that the virus can exist for up to  hours on surfaces.Frequent cleaning is therefore particularly important for communal surfaces like door handles or lt buttons and communal areas like bathrooms, kitchens and tea points.You can see the guidance on GOV.UK and can ask your employeryou have questions.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: best waterside homes uk
story: The awe-inspiring properties, which are now up for sale, give a glimpse into what its like to live in some of the countrys most luxurious settings.The stunning homes dotted around the UK offer tempting glimpses of  destinations that Brits may choose to visit in lieu of a foreign getaway following new quarantine rules on travellers to Britain.Last night, Boris Johnson announced all people arriving in the UK must be quarantined for two weeks to help stop a second coronavirus wave.Airline and tourism bosses fear the two-week quarantine move could kill off any lingering hopes of British holidaymakers heading abroad this summer.Holidaymakers and travellers arriving into the country - including Brits - at ports and airports will be forced to self-isolate for a fortnight, or risk a £, fine or deportation.It means Brits may have to take four weeks off to take a two-week holiday abroad, leaving most people facing summer in the UK during the Covid- pandemic.A study by The National Caravan Councilshowed % of people are likely to take trips in the UK next year, compared to just  per cent before the coronavirus outbreak.One property for sale in a picture-perfect UK resort, the Sharpitor, is an iconic three-bedroom property situated on a clftop in Salcombe, Devon with spellbinding views.Built in , all rooms in the semi-detached Edwardian house have direct access to adjoining terraces to enjoy the spectacular scenery it has to offer, with access to coastal gardens and a small private beach.Another jaw-dropping pad, a ruined th-century rooftop property built on the rocky outcrop just off the beach of North Sands at Salcombe in Devon, is also now up for grabs.The £. million four-bedroom property has an upside-down layout with a hand-built kitchen and conservatory, boasting stunning sea views and gardens terraced into the clf.And a contemporary three-storey beach house in Pwllheli, Gwynedd, Wales taking advantage of amazing clf-side views is now up for £ million.The property boasts two levels of terraces with glass windows and private steps that lead down to the beach and sea, including private shower facilities on the ground level.It is also just a short stroll away from the centre of the nearby picturesque village.One £. million semi-detached house in Exeter on sale boasts a homely interior, large balcony, and first floor sitting with a vaulted ceiling and Juliet balcony for residents to take in the magnicent sea views. The three-bedroom property is located on the banks of the River Exe in Topsham, which  a seaport and centre for shipbuilding - and is now one of the regions most sought out places to live.And in Scotland, the Corriegorm, situated in a forest  in Aberfeldy, Perthshire is a beautul country house with breathtaking views of the Loch Tay.The £, modest building has been transformed into an impressive modern home, with a separate studio apartment, ornamental pond, a hot tub and a boathouse plot available separately with fishing rights on the loch.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: weddings lockdown government
story: In todays report detailing the UKs possible exit from lockdown, the Government announced it is looking at how groups can gather to allow for weddings.The current lockdown measures have been extraordinarily disruptive to peoples lives since March .New guidelines published in a -page document today reveal the Government is investigating whether it’s safe for two homes to mix together.Now being reviewed by SAGE , it could see friends and family finally reunited.In a new outline of Boriss vision, it says: “The Government has asked SAGE to examine whether, when and how it can safely change the regulations to allow people to expand their household group to include one other household in the same exclusive group.“The intention of this change would be to allow those who are isolated some more social contact, and to reduce the most harmful effects of the current social restrictions, while continuing to limit the risks of chains of transmission.“It would also support some families toto work by, for example, allowing two households to share childcare.“This could be based on the New Zealand model of household bubbles where a single ‘bubble’ is the people you live with.”It continues: In addition, the Government is also examining how to enable people to gather in slightly larger groups to better facilitate small weddings.Over the coming weeks, the Government will engage on the nature and timing of the measures in this step, in order to consider the widest possible array of views on how best to balance the health, economic and social effects.It comes after Justice Secretary Robert Buckland told BBC Radio  that he was giving anxious consideration to the effect of potential changes for ceremonies as we enter the next stage of the coronavirus crisis.His comments came after Boris Johnson outlined his roadmap for easing Britain out of the lockdown - but failed to reassure expectant couples when their big days can go ahead.In March, the PM announced a ban on all weddings, baptisms and other ceremonies - although funerals have still been allowed.The issue came up on BBC Radio s Westminster Hour last night - when a list on the show said she was due to be on her honeymoon.Asked about weddings, Mr Buckland said: Youll be glad to know that we are giving anxious consideration to the issue of marriages.We want to help people like you, but there are also some people who are really... they want to get married because things are happening in their le that means they might not be together for a long time, and therefore Im giving a lot of anxious consideration to the effect of the potential changes here as to what we can do with regard to marriage ceremonies.So watch this space, were working on it.Before the ban, the Church of England said the number of people attending church weddings during the crisis should be limited to the legal minimum of five.They said that those attending a wedding should only include the priest, the bride and groom and two witnesses.But councils have since encouraged couples to live stream their nuptials and ceremonies to guests via online s.Mr Johnson last night laid out the first careful steps of easing the lockdown as part of a three-phase plan to get back to normal le.He revealed that most of the strict measures will stay in place for now and failed to mention weddings or any other large gatherings.He did however tell anyone who was unable to work from home that they now would be expected to go back in.He also added that from Wednesday, the Government will encourage everyone to do more exercise.Schools and nurseries will also start to reopen from June  at the earliest, but pubs are expected to stay shut until later in the year.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: pregnant women dont shield leave house keep distance
story: PREGNANT women dont have to shield amid the coronavirus outbreak - but must stick to social distancing rules, the Prime Minister says. In a new -page document detailing changes to lockdown, Boris Johnson reveals that mums-to-be do not have to practice shielding - meaning they are allowed to leave the house.The document reads: It remains the case that some people are more clinically vulnerable to Covid- than others.These include those aged over , those with specic chronic pre-existing conditions and pregnant women.These clinically vulnerable people should continue to take particular care to minimise contact with others outside their households, but do not need to be shielded.Despite this, women who are pregnant with signicant heart disease, congenital or acquired - must practice shielding.The Government defines shielding as staying at home at all times and avoid any face-to-face contact and not leaving the house or attending gatherings at all, with very limited exceptions.Generally, pregnant women do not appear to be more likely to be seriously unwell than other healthy adultsthey develop coronavirus.The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologistssay: It is expected the large majority of pregnant women will experience only mild or moderate cold flu like symptoms.Cough, fever, shortness of breath, headache and loss of sense of smell are other relevant symptoms.More severe symptoms such as pneumonia, seem to be more common in older people, those with weakened immune systems or long-term conditions.As yet, there is no evidence that pregnant women who get this infection are more at risk of serious complications than any other healthy iniduals.There is also no evidence to suggest an increased risk of miscarriageyou do contract coronavirus.Emerging evidence suggests that transmission from a woman to her baby during pregnancy or birth is probable.There has been a report of two cases in which this seems likely, but reassuringly the babies were both discharged from hospital and are well.In all previously reported cases worldwide, infection was found at least  hours after birth.It is important to emphasise that in all reported cases of newborn babies developing coronavirus very soon after birth, the baby was well.Given current evidence, it is considered unlikely thatyou have the virus it would cause problems with a baby’s development, and none have been observed currently.As a precaution, RCOG say  you are pregnant, you should follow government advice about social distancing, stay away from public places and avoid anyone who has symptoms suggestive of coronavirus.It is still considered necessary for pregnant women to go out for essentials, such as food shopping, exercise and to attend antenatal appointments.RCOG say thatyou are in your third trimesteryou should be particularly attentive to social distancing and minimising any contact with others.RCOG say: If you have concerns about the wellbeing of yourself or your unborn baby during your self-isolation period, contact your midwe, or out-of-hours, your maternity team.They will provide further advice, including whether you need to attend hospital.If attendance at the maternity unit or hospital is advised, pregnant women are requested to travel by private transport, or arrange hospital transport, and alert the maternity triage reception once on the premises, prior to entering the hospital.Pregnant women may wish to consider online fitness routines to keep active, such as pregnancy yoga or Pilates.Pregnant women are advised not to attend maternity triage units or AE unless in need of urgent pregnancy or medical care.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
